product.title: Google’s SXSW Talking Shoe
product.body:
a Google art project from SXSW 2013 that offers faint praise or biting sarcasm based on your walking habits

Last year, the company created an entire village near the Convention Center. This year, just outside the convention center, Google has opened a "playground."

It's not intended to be a consumer product — the project comes out of Google's Art, Copy, & Code initiative, whose tagline is "Advertising Re-imagined." With an Arduino board, some key sensors (pedometer, gyroscope, etc.), and a bit of snarky code, the shoe tracks how active you are and will respond accordingly with either faint praise or biting sarcasm.

Google has been showing off a talking shoe at this year’s South by Southwest (SXSW) festival. The shoe monitors the wearer’s activity on Google’s playground at the event, and either gives encouragement or snarky remarks based on level of movement. Whether that sounds like something you’d want to buy or not is irrelevant, because Google has already said it’s not something they’re looking to put into production.

The shoe has a built-in Arduino board connected to a gyroscope, accelerometer, and pedometer. What does it do with this technology? It judges you of course. Lounging around while wearing your Google Talking Shoe? Expect snide comments delivered in the voice of a judgmental British man. If you’re really hustling your way around the obstacles at the playground Google has set up for SXSW, you can expect some words of encouragement.

What you can’t expect to do is buy a pair. They aren’t for sale, and Google says the shoes were not designed as a consumer product. The shoes came out of Google’s Art, Copy, & Code initiative which has the slogan “Advertising Re-Imagined.” Sure, Google could have printed up a bunch of posters or made some videos to show at other events to get attention for their company, but instead they made talking shoes and are giving people a chance to play with them in a heavily branded environment. That’s re-imagined advertising if I’ve ever seen it.

Despite the snarky British attitude, the technology in the shoe isn’t anything groundbreaking. The Arduino board and sensors link back to a computer, or a phone, via Bluetooth and process the information to determine the reply. It basically does what most smartphones are capable of already with fitness tracking apps, just presented in a fun way to get people talking about the cool new thing Google did.

Since the shoes won’t be hitting the market any time soon, or probably ever, if you want to get your hands on a pair to try them out, you’d better get to the Google Playground at SXSW before it’s gone, since we don’t know when or if these things will pop up again.

If you can’t make it to SXSW, the folks at The Verge managed to get their hands on a pair, and spoke with Kate Pacher from Google in this video. Check it out here:

 

Via: The Verge

Video production by John Lagomarsino
product.author: emilie.marmey

product.title: The Thinnest Premium Leather Customizable RFID Blocking Wallet is Australian
product.body:
Stop thieves scanning your credit cards or stealing your identity 

Created by Australian designer James Watson, the Bantam Wallet is the thinnest leather customizable Radio-frequency identification (RFID) blocking wallet. Why an RFID blocking system in a wallet? The safety equipment will block potential theives scanning your credit cards or stealing your identity. Here, the protection is customizable since you can just insert a RIFD super-thin protection in your wallet to block the whole wallet, half, or none.

Minimalist design, durable, light and perfect for any sized pocket

At only 4mm thin (about 5/32inches) and super light, the wallet fits easily into and out of any pocket. Made in Australia using super tough ethical, sustainable and government approved Australian kangaroo leather (thinner than cow leather and far stronger than any other leather in the world) it will keep credit cards safe, and invisible to wandering eyes when it will be open. Also, there is no risk of anything falling out even if you drop it. Despite of its thinness, it allows for a number of cards and cash to be carried. Watson claims you CAN stuff a lot of cards, cash, dockets, post-it-notes, even coins and keys!

Launched on indiegogo today (April 3rd), the wallet will be available for USD$39 (Early Birds supportive price. Changes to AUD$49 after Indiegogo). You can also visit James Watson’s website for further information : JamesWatson.com.au

 RFID blocking sheets
product.tags: wallet,RFID blocking wallet,James Watson,Bantam Wallet,Australian designer,wearable tech,indigogo
product.author: emilie.marmey

product.title: H&M Conscious Collection
product.body:
H&M “ongoing commitment to a more sustainable fashion future"

On march 25th, retailer H&M launched an “eco-conscious” collection entirely made from more sustainable materials, such as organic cotton, recycled polyester, and Tencel. Called Conscious Collection, it includes pieces to suit many different styles like printed trousers, elaborate bombers, easy going tunics and floaty, ruffle-edged yellow sundress, corporate blazers, floral maxi dresses… The range is part of the Swedish brand’s “ongoing commitment to a more sustainable fashion future". H&M also claims it was the biggest user of organic cotton in 2011 and is committing to use only organic cotton and being zero discharge by 2020, according WWD. 

Vanessa Paradis shooting for H&M's new Conscious line. The campaign film was directed by Johan Renck.

A global garment collecting project

Alongside the new collection, the Swedish brand also launched on March 25th a clothing exchange initiative. To encourage customers to recycle garments, participating H&M stores will now collect bags of unwanted clothes. In exchange shoppers will be gifted with an H&M voucher (for 15% off on one item of the customer’s choice). Donated clothes don’t have to be in good condition or carry an H&M label and will be recycled and potentially used to make new clothing. “Our sustainability efforts are rooted in a dedication to social and environmental responsibility,” H&M CEO Karl-Johan Persson said in a statement. “We want to do good for the environment, which is why we are now offering our customers a convenient solution: to be able to leave their worn out or defective garments with H&M.”
product.author: emilie.marmey

product.title: Fashion and Technology Exhibition at FIT - New York City
product.body:
Highlighting the intersection of fashion and technology over the past 250 years

Fashion and Technology, an exhibition running through May 8 2013 at the Museum at FIT (New York City) shows the impact of technology over the past 250 years to present day and poses the question as to what technology is while showing how it has changed culture.

This exhibition shows how culture was impacted by fashion, and, most importantly, is the occasion to see how the fashion industry was impacted with technologies. The introduction of materials such as petroleum, cellophane, PVC and neoprene helped designers to expand their creativity, while the manufacturing processes where revolutionnized with introduction of new equipments and technologies. The jacquard loom for example, allowed common people to have access to woven textiles (that were originally only available to the wealthy). The sewing machines, invented in 1790 by Thomas Saint, generalized mass clothes production as it improved the efficiency and productivity of the clothing industry.

The exhibition also features more recent garments and a great section of wearable tech pieces to show just what’s to come in the future.

For more information, visit the The Museum at FIT

Exhibition Details:

Fashion Institute of Technology 
Address: Seventh Avenue at 27 Street 
Cost: Free
Tuesday – Friday, noon to 8pm
Saturday, 10 am – 5 pm
Closed Sunday, Monday
 
 
Pictures: courtesy The Museum at FIT, New York

product.author: emilie.marmey

product.title: The Secret of The Minute-Repeater
product.body:
What is a Minute Repeater?

A repeater is a complication in a mechanical watch that chimes the time on demand by activating a push or a slide-piece. Each hour, quarter hour and minute has specific tones. By counting the tones and the different tone pattern, it is possible to determine the current time set on the watch. Minute repeater was created before the electric lighting invention in the mid-18th Century. At that time its practical function was to allowed blind people to use a watch, and for everyone else, to be able to determine the time in the dark.

Picture: Blancpain

How it works?

Different types of repeater allow the time to be determined with varying degrees of precision (from quarter-repeater which just strikes the number of hours and quarters, to the minute repeater that sounds the time down to the minute using separate tones for hours, quarter-hours and minutes). Today minute repeater is one of the most complex repeater mechanisms. Here the hours are generally struck in low notes, double strikes of high and low notes indicate the quarters and minutes are sounded in high notes.

Dong Dong Dong, Ding Dong Ding Dong, Ding Ding!

Here you'll have to count the number of hours struck (three), add the the quarters (two = 30mn) and then the minutes (two) to arrive at time of 03:32!

Picture: Blancpain

Why the minute-repeater such a difficult complication to deal with?

The main difficulty of this incredible complication that combines a watch mechanism with a chime that must fits on a wrist, is not only the number of the elements needed to craft it, but also their nature and super tiny size. The minute-repeaters are rare masterpieces of precision mechanical engineering. There is no coincidence if they are craved by collectors and watch lovers. Incidentally, over the past year, around twenty new minute repeaters have been launched in the luxury wristwatch market by brands as diverse in style and heritage as Blancpain, Bulgari, Jaeger LeCoultre, Louis Vuitton, Audemars Piguet, Parmigiani Fleurier, VanCleef & Arpels, Breguet, Patek Philippe, Cartier, Hublot, Ulysse Nardin, Girard-Perregaux or Speake-Marin. 

Picture: Blancpain

Each minute-repeater is in its way unique

 The methods involved to produce such mechanical and acoustic marvels are incompatible with the common search for productivity. Moreover, a  minute-repeater entirely built by an unique watchmaker is a guarantee of its extreme quality. But if each other single craftsman has his style and his ear, are every minute-repeater unique? Is a creator will recognize his work when it returns for a service? The head of the complications workshops at Blancpain, the brand well known for its amazing watch complications, answers: “The watchmaker who assembled {a minute-repeater} will recognize it for sure. Yet on the whole it won’t be any different from another. What we emphasize here is a consistent process, methodology and the handing down of knowledge that sets out and explains what you have to do in each operation from the assembly of subcomponents to the final casing up. The basic work has to be identical. Thereafter you will find the watchmaker’s personal touch, in a decoration for example or in the various widths of a chamfer.”
product.tags: minute repeater,watch complication,blancpain
product.author: emilie.marmey

product.title: FashionLab invites you to attend REFLET(S) exhibition
product.body:
REFLET(S) is a Jewelry exhibition organized by the French committee Francéclat. FashionLab will be part of this event and propose virtual 3D Experiences around High Fine Jewelry.

As a technology incubator dedicated to designers, we – at the FashionLab – are at the crossroads of the fashion and virtual worlds, it combines the technological know-how of Dassault Systèmes with the creativity of designers. Its goal is to provide designers with new experiences of 3D digital creation thanks to dedicated softwares integrating the tools of design, simulation and collaboration.


3D Experiences in High Fine Jewelry

FashionLab tools enable to manipulate 3D creations in an interactive virtual world, bringing various textures, materials or colors.

FashionLab aims to offer new creative perspectives and thus open new spaces of artistic work enhancement. These softwares, used by designers to refine their creative work, offer to the general public experiences revealing the designers’ skills.
This is how FashionLab connects two different worlds: the virtual artistic creation together with hand-made jewelry practices, allowing revolutionizing the way we create jewels.

 
About REFLET(S) Exhibition

This event is organized by Francéclat, a French Committee of watchmaking, jewelry, silversmithing and tableware professionals, organized by Partipris Event Agency.
REFLET(S) exhibition-event is dedicated to jewelry and highlights the designers’ creations.


Event information

Free admission
Location & date: Palais de Tokyo, Paris, from May 29 to June 3, 2013.
Opening times: daily from 11 a.m. to 22 p.m.

More information about REFLET(S)

product.title: Springs 3D-Printed Glasses by Ron Arad for "pq"
product.body:
Glasses frames are 3D printed with nylon powder using selective laser sintering

London designer Ron Arad has designed a coloured collection of 3D-printed glasses for eyewear brand pq. All frames, named after a station on the London Underground's Northern line, are available in a selection of colours.

Angel style from the Springs collection

One monolithic piece of material

The glasses frames, hinges included, are printed with nylon powder and using selective laser sintering (SLS) technology. "It has a stem that's flexible one way and stops the other," said Arad. He added: "The brand wanted to advertise the fact that it's printed but I said let's not go on about it. But it's printed. It's the first pair of glasses that I know about that is one piece of material; it's monolithic. It's polyamide."

Balham style from the Springs collection

 

Archway style from the Springs collection


Yellow style: Highgate style from the Springs collection

product.title: Ressence Type 3 Watch : An Unique Way to Display Time
product.body:
Purity and minimalism

With a total of total of 407 components and a weight of 175 grams, the design of the Ressence Type 3 Watch is characterized by its purity and minimalims. But this wristwatch real particularity is its unique way to display time: the constantly orbiting indications discs are bathed in a fluid that refracts light like air, so that the indications appear to be displayed directly onto the sapphire crystal exterior. 

Type 3 Technical Specifications

This futuristic wristwatch uses a completely new time of mechanism. There is no Crown here. Instead, the Type 3 watch features a gravitational gear system with information transmitted from movement to indications by micro-magnetic fields, through which it is possible to adjust the time and date. The watch allowed to read the Date, Days, Hours, Minutes, Seconds (360’’) and is made of a sandwich construction with titanium membrane between movement and fluid-filled indication module and a sapphire crystal and grade 5 titanium case.

The Ressence Type 3 will be available at ressence.eu in few days for €23,000.
